revision.comment: Reverted 1 edit by [[Special:Contributions/85.194.216.146|85.194.216.146]] ([[User talk:85.194.216.146|talk]]) to last revision by Brian W. Schaller. ([[WP:TW|TW]])
revision.text:
[[File:RNS Yellowstone 13399u.jpg|thumb|1938 poster promoting [[Yellowstone National Park]], the first [[national park]] in the world]] [[File:NationalParks.forwiki.pdf|thumb|Symbolic representation of visitors at each national park (2014)]] The [[United States]] has 60 [[protected area]]s known as national parks{{Cite web |url=https://www.nps.gov/aboutus/national-park-system.htm |title=National Park System (U.S. National Park Service) |date=2018-03-15}} that are operated by the [[National Park Service]], an agency of the [[United States Department of the Interior|Department of the Interior]]. National parks must be established by an act of the [[United States Congress]]. A bill creating the first national park, [[Yellowstone National Park|Yellowstone]], was signed into law by President [[Ulysses S. Grant]] in 1872, followed by [[Mackinac National Park]] in 1875 (decommissioned in 1895), and then [[Rock Creek Park]] (later merged into [[National Capital Parks]]), [[Sequoia National Park|Sequoia]] and [[Yosemite National Park|Yosemite]] in 1890. The [[National Park Service Organic Act|Organic Act]] of 1916 created the National Park Service "to conserve the scenery and the natural and historic objects and wildlife therein, and to provide for the enjoyment of the same in such manner and by such means as will leave them unimpaired for the enjoyment of future generations."{{cite web|url=https://www.nature.nps.gov/air/Regs/npsOrganic.cfm|title=NPS Organic Act Overview|date=17 January 2007|website=nature.nps.gov|publisher=National Park Service|accessdate=26 February 2017|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170206142738/https://www.nature.nps.gov/air/regs/npsorganic.cfm|archivedate=6 February 2017|deadurl=no}} Many current national parks had been previously protected as [[National Monument (United States)|national monuments]] by the president under the [[Antiquities Act]] before being upgraded by Congress. Seven national parks (including six in [[Alaska]]) are paired with a [[national preserve]], areas with different levels of protection that are administered together but considered separate [[List of the United States National Park System official units|units]] and whose areas are not included in the figures below. Criteria for the selection of national parks include natural beauty, unique geological features, unusual ecosystems, and recreational opportunities (though these criteria are not always considered together). National monuments, on the other hand, are frequently chosen for their historical or archaeological significance. Fourteen national parks are designated [[UNESCO]] [[World Heritage Site]]s (WHS),{{cite web|url=http://whc.unesco.org/en/list/?search=&searchSites=&search_by_country=United+States®ion=&search_yearinscribed=&themes=&criteria_restrication=&type=&media=&order=country&description= |title=World Heritage List - United States of America |website=whc.unesco.org |publisher=UNESCO World Heritage Centre |accessdate=25 February 2017 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170225001929/http://whc.unesco.org/en/list/?search=&searchSites=&search_by_country=United%2BStates®ion=&search_yearinscribed=&themes=&criteria_restrication=&type=&media=&order=country&description= |archivedate=25 February 2017 |deadurl=no |df= }} while 21 national parks are designated UNESCO [[Man and the Biosphere Programme#Biosphere reserves|Biosphere Reserves]] (BR).{{cite web|url=http://www.unesco.org/new/en/natural-sciences/environment/ecological-sciences/biosphere-reserves/europe-north-america/united-states-of-america/ |title=UNESCO » Biosphere Reserves » United States of America |date=November 2015 |website=unesco.org |publisher=UNESCO |accessdate=22 February 2017 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170222235151/http://www.unesco.org/new/en/natural-sciences/environment/ecological-sciences/biosphere-reserves/europe-north-america/united-states-of-america/ |archivedate=22 February 2017 |deadurl=no |df= }} Eight national parks are designated in both UNESCO programs. Twenty-eight states have national parks, as do the territories of [[American Samoa]] and the [[United States Virgin Islands]]. [[California]] has the most (nine), followed by [[Alaska]] (eight), [[Utah]] (five), and [[Colorado]] (four). The largest national park is [[Wrangell–St. Elias National Park and Preserve|Wrangell–St. Elias]] in Alaska: at over {{convert|8|e6acre|km2|0}}, it is larger than each of the [[List of U.S. states and territories by area|nine smallest states]]. The next three largest parks are also in Alaska. The smallest park is [[Gateway Arch National Park]], [[Missouri]], at approximately {{convert|192.83|acre|km2}}. The total area protected by national parks is approximately {{convert|52.2|e6acre|km2}}, for an average of {{convert|870|e3acre|km2}} but a [[median]] of only {{convert|229|e3acre|km2}}.{{cite book|title=The National Parks: Index 2012–2016|publisher=National Park Service|location=Washington, D.C.|url=https://www.nps.gov/aboutus/upload/NPIndex2012-2016.pdf|accessdate=19 November 2018|format=PDF|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20181113065657/https://www.nps.gov/aboutus/upload/NPIndex2012-2016.pdf|archivedate=13 November 2018|deadurl=no}} The national parks set a visitation record in 2017, with more than 84 million visitors.{{cite web|title=Annual Visitation by Park Type or Region for: 2017 By Park Type|url=https://irma.nps.gov/Stats/SSRSReports/National%20Reports/Annual%20Visitation%20by%20Park%20Type%20or%20Region%20(1979%20-%20Last%20Calendar%20Year)|website=Irma.NPS.gov|accessdate=1 March 2018}} The most-visited national park is [[Great Smoky Mountains National Park]] in North Carolina and Tennessee, with over 11.3 million visitors in 2017, followed by Arizona's [[Grand Canyon National Park]], with over 6.2 million. In contrast, only 11,177 people visited the remote [[Gates of the Arctic National Park and Preserve]] in Alaska in the same year. A few former national parks are [[List of areas in the United States National Park System#Disbanded national parks|no longer designated as such]], or have been disbanded. Other units of the National Park Service ({{National Park Units}} altogether) are broadly referred to as national parks within the [[List of areas in the United States National Park System|National Park System]]."{{cite web|url=https://www.nationalparks.org/connect/blog/how-many-national-parks-are-there |title=How many national parks are there? |website=nationalparks.org |publisher=National Park Foundation |last=Lower |first=Rocío |date=17 October 2016 |accessdate=24 February 2017 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170222145445/https://www.nationalparks.org/connect/blog/how-many-national-parks-are-there |archivedate=22 February 2017 |deadurl=no |quote=The National Park System encompasses 417 national parks in the United States.... Within the system, there are 59 sites that include 'National Park' as part of their proper name}} == National parks == {{legend|#cfecd2|Green shading{{snd}}UNESCO designated [[List of World Heritage Sites in the United States|World Heritage Sites]] (a * symbol also appears after the park's name)|border=solid 1px #AAAAAA}} {{legend|#cedff2|Blue shading{{snd}}UNESCO designated [[Man and the Biosphere Programme#Biosphere reserves|Biosphere Reserves]] (a {{dagger}} symbol also appears)|border=solid 1px #AAAAAA}} {{legend|#ddcef2|Purple shading{{snd}}parks designated in both UNESCO programs (a {{double dagger}} symbol also appears)|border=solid 1px #AAAAAA}} {| class="wikitable sortable plainrowheaders" style="width:98%" !scope="col" | Name !scope="col" class="unsortable"| Image !scope="col" | Location !scope="col" |Date established as park{{cite web|url=http://home.nps.gov/applications/budget2/documents/chronop.pdf |title=National Park System Areas Listed in Chronological Order of Date Authorized under DOI |date=27 June 2005 |publisher=National Park Service |accessdate=18 January 2010 |format=PDF |deadurl=unfit |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120311003821/http://home.nps.gov/applications/budget2/documents/chronop.pdf |archivedate=March 11, 2012 }} !scope="col" |Area (2017){{cite web|title=National Reports|url=https://irma.nps.gov/Stats/Reports/National|work=National Park Service|accessdate=23 February 2018|quote=Click on ''Park Acreage Reports (1997 – Last Calendar/Fiscal Year)'', then select ''By Park'', ''Calendar Year'', , and then click the ''View PDF Report'' button - the areas used here are the ''Gross Area Acres'' which are in the final column of the report}} !scope="col" |Recreation visitors (2017){{cite web|title=Annual Park Ranking Report for Recreation Visitors in: 2017|url=https://irma.nps.gov/Stats/SSRSReports/National%20Reports/Annual%20Park%20Ranking%20Report%20(1979%20-%20Last%20Calendar%20Year)|website=irma.nps.gov|publisher=National Park Service|accessdate=26 February 2018}} !scope="col" class="unsortable"|{{Abbr|Description|Park description; (WHS){{snd}}park is a UNESCO World Heritage Site; (BR){{snd}}park is a UNESCO Biosphere Reserve}} |- !scope="row" | [[Acadia National Park|Acadia]] |[[File:Bass Harbor Head Light Station 2016.jpg|200px]] |[[Maine]]
{{coord|44.35|-68.21|name=Acadia|type:landmark}} |{{dts|February 26, 1919}} |{{convert|49075.26|acre|km2|1|sortable=on}} |3,509,271 |Covering most of [[Mount Desert Island]] and other coastal islands, Acadia features the [[Cadillac Mountain|tallest mountain on the Atlantic coast of the United States]], granite peaks, ocean shoreline, woodlands, and lakes. There are freshwater, estuary, forest, and intertidal habitats.{{cite web|url=http://www.nps.gov/acad/|title=Acadia National Park|publisher=National Park Service|accessdate=23 March 2010}}{{cite web|url=http://www.nps.gov/acad/planyourvisit/placestogo.htm|title=Acadia National Park Places To Go|publisher=National Park Service|accessdate=28 January 2014}} |- !scope="row" | [[National Park of American Samoa|American Samoa]] |[[File:Ofu Beach NPS.jpg|200px]] |[[American Samoa]]
{{coord|-14.25|-170.68|name=National Park of American Samoa|type:landmark}} |{{dts|October 31, 1988}} |{{convert|8256.67|acre|km2|1|sortable=on}} |69,468 |The southernmost national park is on three Samoan islands and protects [[coral reef]]s, rainforests, volcanic mountains, and white beaches. The area is also home to [[Samoa flying-fox|flying foxes]], [[brown booby|brown boobies]], sea turtles, and 900 species of fish.{{cite web|url=http://www.nps.gov/npsa/|title=National Park of American Samoa|publisher=National Park Service|accessdate=23 March 2010}} |- !scope="row" | [[Arches National Park|Arches]] |[[File:Delicatearch1.jpg|200px]] |[[Utah]]
{{coord|38.68|-109.57|name=Arches|type:landmark}} |{{dts|November 12, 1971}} |{{convert|76678.98|acre|km2|1|sortable=on}} |1,539,028 |This site features more than 2,000 [[Natural arch|natural sandstone arches]], with some of the most popular arches in the park being [[Delicate Arch]], [[Landscape Arch]] and [[Double Arch]].{{cite web|url=https://www.nps.gov/arch/learn/nature/rockstars.htm|title=Arches National Park - Arches Rock Stars|publisher=National Park Service|accessdate=25 February 2017}} Millions of years of erosion have created these structures located in a desert climate where the arid ground has life-sustaining [[biological soil crust]]s and potholes that serve as natural water-collecting basins. Other geologic formations include stone [[Pinnacle (geology)|pinnacles]], [[Fin (geology)|fins]], and [[balancing rock]]s.{{cite web|url=http://www.nps.gov/arch/|title=Arches National Park|publisher=National Park Service|accessdate=23 March 2010}} |- !scope="row" | [[Badlands National Park|Badlands]] |[[File:BadlandsView3.jpg|200px]] |[[South Dakota]]
{{coord|43.75|-102.50|name=Badlands|type:landmark}} |{{dts|November 10, 1978}} |{{convert|242755.94|acre|km2|1|sortable=on}} |1,054,325 |The Badlands are a collection of [[butte]]s, pinnacles, spires, and [[Mixed grass prairie|mixed-grass prairies]]. The [[White River (Missouri River)|White River]] Badlands contain the largest assemblage of known late [[Eocene]] and [[Oligocene]] mammal fossils.{{cite web|url=https://www.nps.gov/badl/learn/nature/fossils.htm|title=Badlands National Park - Fossils|publisher=National Park Service|accessdate=25 February 2017}} The wildlife includes [[bison]], [[bighorn sheep]], [[black-footed ferret]]s, and [[prairie dog]]s.{{cite web|url=http://www.nps.gov/badl/|title=Badlands National Park|publisher=National Park Service|accessdate=23 March 2010}} |- |scope="row" bgcolor="#cedff2"| [[Big Bend National Park|Big Bend]] {{dagger}} |[[File:Big Bend National Park PB112573.jpg|200px]] |[[Texas]]
{{coord|29.25|-103.25|name=Big Bend|type:landmark}} |{{dts|June 12, 1944}} |{{convert|801163.21|acre|km2|1|sortable=on}} |440,276 |Named for the [[Big Bend, Texas|prominent bend]] in the [[Rio Grande]] along the U.S.–Mexico border, this park encompasses a large and remote part of the [[Chihuahuan Desert]]. Its main attraction is backcountry recreation in the arid [[Chisos Mountains]] and in canyons along the river. A wide variety of [[Cretaceous]] and [[Tertiary]] fossils as well as cultural artifacts of Native Americans also exist within its borders.{{cite web|url=http://www.nps.gov/bibe/|title=Big Bend National Park|date=December 8, 2009|publisher=National Park Service|accessdate=}} (BR){{cite web|url=http://www.unesco.org/new/en/natural-sciences/environment/ecological-sciences/biosphere-reserves/europe-north-america/united-states-of-america/big-bend/ |title=Big Bend Biosphere Reserve and National Park |website=unesco.org |publisher=UNESCO |accessdate=24 February 2017 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170224215310/http://www.unesco.org/new/en/natural-sciences/environment/ecological-sciences/biosphere-reserves/europe-north-america/united-states-of-america/big-bend/ |archivedate=24 February 2017 |deadurl=no |df= }} |- !scope="row" | [[Biscayne National Park|Biscayne]] |[[File:Biscayne NP snorkeling.jpg|200px]] |[[Florida]]
{{coord|25.65|-80.08|name=Biscayne|type:landmark}} |{{dts|June 28, 1980}} |{{convert|172971.11|acre|km2|1|sortable=on}} |446,961 |Located in [[Biscayne Bay]], this park at the north end of the [[Florida Keys]] has four interrelated marine ecosystems: [[mangrove]] forest, the Bay, the Keys, and coral reefs. Threatened animals include the [[West Indian manatee]], [[American crocodile]], various sea turtles, and [[peregrine falcon]].{{cite web|url=http://www.nps.gov/bisc/|title=Biscayne National Park|publisher=National Park Service|accessdate=23 March 2010}} |- !scope="row" | [[Black Canyon of the Gunnison National Park|Black Canyon of the Gunnison]] |[[File:Black canyon gunnison Colorado.jpg|200px]] |[[Colorado]]
{{coord|38.57|-107.72|name=Black Canyon of the Gunnison|type:landmark}} |{{dts|October 21, 1999}} |{{convert|30780.76|acre|km2|1|sortable=on}} |307,143 |The park protects a quarter of the [[Gunnison River]], which slices sheer canyon walls from dark [[Precambrian]]-era rock. The canyon features some of the steepest cliffs and oldest rock in North America, and is a popular site for river rafting and rock climbing. The deep, narrow canyon is composed of [[gneiss]] and [[schist]] which appears black when in shadow.{{cite web|url=http://www.nps.gov/blca/|title=Black Canyon of the Gunnison National Park|publisher=National Park Service|accessdate=23 March 2010}} |- !scope="row" | [[Bryce Canyon National Park|Bryce Canyon]] |[[File:Bryce Canyon Hoodoos Amphitheater.jpg|200px]] |[[Utah]]
{{coord|37.57|-112.18|name=Bryce Canyon|type:landmark}} |{{dts|February 25, 1928}} |{{convert|35835.08|acre|km2|1|sortable=on}} |2,571,684 |Bryce Canyon is a geological [[amphitheater]] on the [[Paunsaugunt Plateau]] with hundreds of tall, multicolored [[Hoodoo (geology)|sandstone hoodoos]] formed by erosion. The region was originally settled by Native Americans and later by [[Mormon]] pioneers.{{cite web|url=http://www.nps.gov/brca/|title=Bryce Canyon National Park|publisher=National Park Service|accessdate=23 March 2010}} |- !scope="row" | [[Canyonlands National Park|Canyonlands]] |[[File:Canyonlands National Park…Needles area (6294480744).jpg|200px]] |[[Utah]]
{{coord|38.2|-109.93|name=Canyonlands|type:landmark}} |{{dts|September 12, 1964}} |{{convert|337597.83|acre|km2|1|sortable=on}} |742,271 |This landscape was eroded into a maze of canyons, buttes, and mesas by the combined efforts of the [[Colorado River]], [[Green River (Colorado River)|Green River]], and their [[tributaries]], which divide the park into three districts. {{coord|38.20|-111.17|name=Capitol Reef|type:landmark}} |{{dts|December 18, 1971}} |{{convert|241904.50|acre|km2|1|sortable=on}} |1,150,165 |The park's [[Waterpocket Fold]] is a {{convert|100|mi|km|adj=on}} [[monocline]] that exhibits the earth's diverse geologic layers. {{coord|32.17|-104.44|name=Carlsbad Caverns|type:landmark}} |{{dts|May 14, 1930}} |{{convert|46766.45|acre|km2|1|sortable=on}} |520,026 |Carlsbad Caverns has 117 caves, the longest of which is over {{convert|120|mi|km}} long. Above ground are the [[Chihuahuan Desert]] and Rattlesnake Springs.{{cite web|url=http://www.nps.gov/cave/|title=Carlsbad Caverns National Park|publisher=National Park Service|accessdate=23 March 2010}} (WHS){{cite web|url=http://whc.unesco.org/en/list/721 |title=World Heritage List - Carlsbad Caverns National Park |website=unesco.org |publisher=UNESCO |accessdate=24 February 2017 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170224235812/http://whc.unesco.org/en/list/721 |archivedate=24 February 2017 |deadurl=no}} |- |scope="row" bgcolor="#cedff2"| [[Channel Islands National Park|Channel Islands]] {{dagger}} |[[File:Channel Islands National Park.jpg|200px]] |[[California]]
{{coord|34.01|-119.42|name=Channel Islands|type:landmark}} |{{dts|March 5, 1980}} |{{convert|249561.00|acre|km2|1|sortable=on}} |383,687 |Five of the eight [[Channel Islands of California|Channel Islands]] are protected, and half of the park's area is underwater. They are home to over 2,000 species of land plants and animals, and 145 are unique to them, including the [[island fox]]. Ferry services offer transportation to the islands from the mainland.{{cite web|url=http://www.nps.gov/chis/|title=Channel Islands National Park|publisher=National Park Service|accessdate=23 March 2010}} (BR){{cite web|url=http://www.unesco.org/new/en/natural-sciences/environment/ecological-sciences/biosphere-reserves/europe-north-america/united-states-of-america/channel-islands/ |title=Channel Islands Biosphere Reserve |website=unesco.org |publisher=UNESCO |accessdate=24 February 2017 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170224221017/http://www.unesco.org/new/en/natural-sciences/environment/ecological-sciences/biosphere-reserves/europe-north-america/united-states-of-america/channel-islands/ |archivedate=24 February 2017 |deadurl=no |df= }} |- |scope="row" bgcolor="#cedff2"| [[Congaree National Park|Congaree]] {{dagger}} |[[File:Bald cypress and creek (7166139814).jpg|200px]] |[[South Carolina]]
{{coord|33.78|-80.78|name=Congaree|type:landmark}} |{{dts|November 10, 2003}} |{{convert|26539.22|acre|km2|1|sortable=on}} |159,595 |On the [[Congaree River]], this park is the largest portion of [[old-growth]] floodplain forest left in North America. {{coord|42.94|-122.1|name=Crater Lake|type:landmark}} |{{dts|May 22, 1902}} |{{convert|183224.05|acre|km2|1|sortable=on}} |711,749 |[[Crater Lake]] lies in the caldera of an ancient volcano called [[Mount Mazama]] that collapsed 7,700 years ago. The lake is the deepest in the United States and is noted for its vivid blue color and water clarity. [[Wizard Island]] and the [[Phantom Ship (island)|Phantom Ship]] are more recent volcanic formations within the caldera. As the lake has no inlets or outlets, the lake is replenished only by precipitation.{{cite web|url=http://www.nps.gov/crla/|title=Crater Lake National Park|publisher=National Park Service|accessdate=23 March 2010}} |- !scope="row" | [[Cuyahoga Valley National Park|Cuyahoga Valley]] |[[File:Cuyahoga Valley National Park 03.jpg|200px]] |[[Ohio]]
{{coord|41.24|-81.55|name=Cuyahoga Valley|type:landmark}} |{{dts|October 11, 2000}} |{{convert|32572.35|acre|km2|1|sortable=on}} |2,226,879 |This park along the [[Cuyahoga River]] has waterfalls, hills, trails, and exhibits on early rural living. The park has numerous historic homes, bridges, and structures,{{cite web|url=http://www.nps.gov/cuva/|title=Cuyahoga Valley National Park|publisher=National Park Service|accessdate=23 March 2010}} and also offers a scenic train ride.{{cite web|url=http://www.nps.gov/cuva/planyourvisit/train.htm|title=Cuyahoga Valley National Park Scenic Railroad|publisher=National Park Service|accessdate=4 November 2012}} |- |scope="row" bgcolor="#cedff2"| [[Death Valley National Park|Death Valley]] {{dagger}} |[[File:Mesquite Sand Dunes in Death Valley.jpg|200px]] |[[California]], [[Nevada]]
{{coord|36.24|-116.82|name=Death Valley|type:landmark}} |{{dts|October 31, 1994}} |{{convert|3373063.14|acre|km2|1|sortable=on}} |1,294,827 |[[Death Valley]] is the hottest, lowest, and driest place in the United States, with daytime temperatures that have exceeded 130 °F (54 °C). {{coord|24.63|-82.87|name=Dry Tortugas|type:landmark}} |{{dts|October 26, 1992}} |{{convert|64701.22|acre|km2|1|sortable=on}} |54,281 |The islands of the [[Dry Tortugas]], at the westernmost end of the Florida Keys, are the site of [[Fort Jefferson (Florida)|Fort Jefferson]], a [[American Civil War|Civil War]]-era fort that is the largest [[masonry]] structure in the Western Hemisphere. The park is home to undisturbed coral reefs and shipwrecks, and is only accessible by plane or boat.{{cite web|url=http://www.nps.gov/drto/|title=Dry Tortugas National Park|publisher=National Park Service|accessdate=23 March 2010}} (BR){{cite web|url=http://www.unesco.org/new/en/natural-sciences/environment/ecological-sciences/biosphere-reserves/europe-north-america/united-states-of-america/everglades-dry-tortugas/ |title=Everglades & Dry Tortugas Biosphere Reserve |website=unesco.org |publisher=UNESCO |accessdate=24 February 2017 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170224223308/http://www.unesco.org/new/en/natural-sciences/environment/ecological-sciences/biosphere-reserves/europe-north-america/united-states-of-america/everglades-dry-tortugas/ |archivedate=24 February 2017 |deadurl=no |df= }} |- |scope="row" bgcolor="#ddcef2"| [[Everglades National Park|Everglades]] {{double dagger}} |[[File:Everglades National Park cypress.jpg|200px]] |[[Florida]]
{{coord|25.32|-80.93|name=Everglades|type:landmark}} |{{dts|May 30, 1934}} |{{convert|1508934.25|acre|km2|1|sortable=on}} |1,018,557 |The [[Everglades]] are the largest tropical wilderness in the United States. Some areas have been drained and developed; restoration projects aim to restore the ecology.{{cite web|url=http://www.nps.gov/ever/|title=Everglades National Park|publisher=National Park Service|accessdate=23 March 2010}} (WHS){{cite web|url=http://whc.unesco.org/en/list/76 |title=World Heritage List - Everglades National Park |website=unesco.org |publisher=UNESCO |accessdate=24 February 2017 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170224234515/http://whc.unesco.org/en/list/76 |archivedate=24 February 2017 |deadurl=no}} (BR) |- !scope="row" | [[Gates of the Arctic National Park and Preserve|Gates of the Arctic]] |[[File:GatesofArctic.jpg|200px]] |[[Alaska]]
{{coord|67.78|-153.30|name=Gates of the Arctic|type:landmark}} |{{dts|December 2, 1980}} |{{convert|7523897.45|acre|km2|1|sortable=on}} |11,177 |The country's northernmost park protects an expanse of pure wilderness in Alaska's [[Brooks Range]] and has no park facilities. {{coord|38.63|-90.19|name=Gateway Arch|type:landmark}} |{{dts|February 22, 2018}}{{cite web|url=https://www.whitehouse.gov/briefings-statements/president-donald-j-trump-signs-s-1438-law/|title=President Donald J. Trump Signs S. 1438 into Law|date=February 22, 2018|website=whitehouse.gov|publisher=The White House|accessdate=19 November 2018|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20180222225941/https://www.whitehouse.gov/briefings-statements/president-donald-j-trump-signs-s-1438-law/|archivedate=22 February 2018|deadurl=no}} |{{convert|192.83|acre|km2|1|sortable=on}} |1,398,188 |The Gateway Arch is a {{convert|630|ft|m|0|adj=on}} (both high and wide) [[catenary]] arch built to commemorate the [[Lewis and Clark Expedition]], initiated by [[Thomas Jefferson]], and the subsequent [[United States territorial acquisitions|westward expansion]] of the country. The nearby [[Old Courthouse (St. Louis)|Old Courthouse]], across a [[Greenway (landscape)|greenway]] to the west of the arch, was the first site of the ''[[Dred Scott v. Sandford|Dred Scott]]'' case about slavery. A museum, located in the underground visitor center below the arch, describes the arch's construction and the country's westward expansion.{{cite web|url=http://www.nps.gov/jeff/index.htm/|title=Jefferson National Expansion Memorial|publisher=National Park Service|accessdate=23 February 2018}} |- |scope="row" bgcolor="#ddcef2"| [[Glacier National Park (U.S.)|Glacier]] {{double dagger}} |[[File:St Mary Lake - Wild goose Island.jpg|200px]] |[[Montana]]
{{coord|48.80|-114.00|name=Glacier|type:landmark}} |{{dts|May 11, 1910}} |{{convert|1013125.99|acre|km2|1|sortable=on}} |3,305,512 |The U.S. half of [[Waterton-Glacier International Peace Park]], this park includes 26 glaciers and 130 named lakes surrounded by Rocky Mountain peaks. {{coord|58.50|-137.00|name=Glacier Bay|type:landmark}} |{{dts|December 2, 1980}} |{{convert|3223383.43|acre|km2|1|sortable=on}} |547,057 |Glacier Bay contains tidewater glaciers, mountains, fjords, and a temperate rainforest, and is home to large populations of grizzly bears, mountain goats, whales, seals, and eagles. When discovered in 1794 by [[George Vancouver]], the entire bay was covered by ice, but the glaciers have since receded more than {{convert|65|mi|km}}.{{cite web|url=http://www.nps.gov/glba/|title=Glacier Bay National Park|publisher=National Park Service|accessdate=23 March 2010}} (WHS) (BR){{cite web|url=http://www.unesco.org/mabdb/br/brdir/directory/biores.asp?code=USA+41&mode=all |title=Glacier Bay and Admiralty Island Biosphere Reserve |website=unesco.org |publisher=UNESCO |accessdate=24 February 2017 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170224231453/http://www.unesco.org/mabdb/br/brdir/directory/biores.asp?code=USA%2B41&mode=all |archivedate=24 February 2017 |deadurl=no |df= }} |- |scope="row" bgcolor="#cfecd2"| [[Grand Canyon National Park|Grand Canyon]] * |[[File:USA 09847 Grand Canyon Luca Galuzzi 2007.jpg|200px]] |[[Arizona]]
{{coord|36.06|-112.14|name=Grand Canyon|type:landmark}} |{{dts|February 26, 1919}} |{{convert|1201647.03|acre|km2|1|sortable=on}} |6,254,238 |The [[Grand Canyon]], carved by the mighty [[Colorado River]], is {{convert|277|mi|km}} long, up to 1 mile (1.6 km) deep, and up to {{convert|15|mi|km}} wide. {{coord|43.73|-110.80|name=Grand Teton|type:landmark}} |{{dts|February 26, 1929}} |{{convert|310044.22|acre|km2|1|sortable=on}} |3,317,000 |[[Grand Teton]] is the tallest mountain in the [[Teton Range]]. The park's historic [[Jackson Hole]] and reflective piedmont lakes teem with [[Endemism|endemic]] wildlife, with a backdrop of craggy mountains that rise abruptly from the sage-covered valley.{{cite web|url=http://www.nps.gov/grte/|title=Grand Teton National Park|publisher=National Park Service|accessdate=23 March 2010}} |- !scope="row" | [[Great Basin National Park|Great Basin]] |[[File:Prometheus Wheeler.jpg|200px]] |[[Nevada]]
{{coord|38.98|-114.30|name=Great Basin|type:landmark}} |{{dts|October 27, 1986}} |{{convert|77180.00|acre|km2|1|sortable=on}} |168,028 |Based around Nevada's second tallest mountain, [[Wheeler Peak (Nevada)|Wheeler Peak]], [[Great Basin]] National Park contains 5,000-year-old [[bristlecone pine]]s, a [[Wheeler Peak Glacier|rock glacier]], and the limestone [[Lehman Caves]]. Due to its remote location, the park has some of the country's darkest night skies. Wildlife includes the [[Townsend's big-eared bat]], [[pronghorn]], and [[Bonneville cutthroat trout]].{{cite web|url=http://www.nps.gov/grba/|title=Great Basin National Park|publisher=National Park Service|accessdate=23 March 2010}} |- !scope="row" | [[Great Sand Dunes National Park and Preserve|Great Sand Dunes]] |[[File:Coloradodunes.jpg|200px]] |[[Colorado]]
{{coord|37.73|-105.51|name=Great Sand Dunes|type:landmark}} |{{dts|September 13, 2004}} |{{convert|107341.87|acre|km2|1|sortable=on}} |486,935 |The tallest sand dunes in North America, up to {{convert|750|ft|m}} tall, were formed by deposits of the ancient [[Rio Grande]] in the [[San Luis Valley]]. Abutting a variety of grasslands, shrublands, and wetlands, the park also has alpine lakes, six 13,000-foot mountains, and old-growth forests.{{cite web|url=http://www.nps.gov/grsa/|title=Great Sand Dunes National Park|publisher=National Park Service|accessdate=23 March 2010}} |- |scope="row" bgcolor="#ddcef2"| [[Great Smoky Mountains National Park|Great Smoky Mountains]] {{double dagger}} |[[File:Fall at Oconaluftee Overlook.JPG|200px]] |[[Tennessee]], [[North Carolina]]
{{coord|35.68|-83.53|name=Great Smoky Mountains|type:landmark}} |{{dts|June 15, 1934}} |{{convert|522426.88|acre|km2|1|sortable=on}} |11,338,893 |The [[Great Smoky Mountains]], part of the [[Appalachian Mountains]], span a wide range of elevations, making them home to over 400 vertebrate species, 100 tree species, and 5000 plant species. Hiking is the park's main attraction, with over {{convert|800|mi|km}} of trails, including {{convert|70|mi|km}} of the [[Appalachian Trail]]. Other activities include fishing, horseback riding, and touring nearly 80 historic structures.{{cite web|url=http://www.nps.gov/grsm/|title=Great Smoky Mountains National Park|publisher=National Park Service|accessdate=23 March 2010}} (WHS){{cite web|url=http://whc.unesco.org/en/list/259 |title=World Heritage List - Great Smoky Mountains National Park |website=unesco.org |publisher=UNESCO |accessdate=24 February 2017 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170224235444/http://whc.unesco.org/en/list/259 |archivedate=24 February 2017 |deadurl=no}} (BR){{cite web|url=http://www.unesco.org/mabdb/br/brdir/directory/biores.asp?code=USA+44&mode=all |title=Southern Appalachian Biosphere Reserve |website=unesco.org |publisher=UNESCO |accessdate=24 February 2017 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170224231827/http://www.unesco.org/mabdb/br/brdir/directory/biores.asp?code=USA%2B44&mode=all |archivedate=24 February 2017 |deadurl=no |df= }} |- !scope="row" | [[Guadalupe Mountains National Park|Guadalupe Mountains]] |[[File:West face of Guadalupe Mountains at sunset 2006.jpg|200px]] |[[Texas]]
{{coord|31.92|-104.87|name=Guadalupe Mountains|type:landmark}} |{{dts|October 15, 1966}} |{{convert|86367.10|acre|km2|1|sortable=on}} |225,257 |This park contains [[Guadalupe Peak]], the highest point in Texas, as well as the scenic [[McKittrick Canyon]] filled with [[bigtooth maple]]s, a corner of the arid [[Chihuahuan Desert]], and a fossilized coral reef from the [[Permian]] era.{{cite web|url=http://www.nps.gov/gumo/|title=Guadalupe Mountains National Park|publisher=National Park Service|accessdate=23 March 2010}} |- |scope="row" bgcolor="#cedff2"| [[Haleakalā National Park|Haleakalā]] {{dagger}} |[[File:Haleakala Crater.jpg|200px]] |[[Hawaii]]
{{coord|20.72|-156.17|name=Haleakalā|type:landmark}} |{{dts|August 1, 1916}} |{{convert|33264.62|acre|km2|1|sortable=on}} |1,112,390 |The [[Haleakalā]] volcano on [[Maui]] features a very large crater with numerous [[cinder cone]]s, [[Hosmer's Grove]] of alien trees, the [[Kipahulu]] section's scenic pools of freshwater fish, and the native [[Hawaiian goose]]. The park protects the greatest number of endangered species within a U.S. National Park.{{cite web|url=http://www.nps.gov/hale/|title=Haleakala National Park|publisher=National Park Service|accessdate=23 March 2010}} (BR){{cite web|url=http://www.unesco.org/mabdb/br/brdir/directory/biores.asp?code=USA+32&mode=all |title=Hawaiian Islands Biosphere Reserve |website=unesco.org |publisher=UNESCO |accessdate=24 February 2017 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170224230939/http://www.unesco.org/mabdb/br/brdir/directory/biores.asp?code=USA%2B32&mode=all |archivedate=24 February 2017 |deadurl=no |df= }} |- |scope="row" bgcolor="#ddcef2"| [[Hawaiʻi Volcanoes National Park|Hawaiʻi Volcanoes]] {{double dagger}} |[[File:Puu Oo cropped.jpg|200px]] |[[Hawaii]]
{{coord|19.38|-155.20|name=Hawaiʻi Volcanoes|type:landmark}} |{{dts|August 1, 1916}} |{{convert|323431.38|acre|km2|1|sortable=on}} |2,016,702 |This park on the [[Hawaii (island)|Big Island]] protects the [[Kīlauea]] and [[Mauna Loa]] volcanoes, two of the world's most active geological features. Diverse ecosystems range from tropical forests at sea level to barren lava beds at more than {{convert|13000|ft|m}}.{{cite web|url=http://www.nps.gov/havo/|title=Hawaii Volcanoes National Park|publisher=National Park Service|accessdate=23 March 2010}} (WHS){{cite web|url=http://whc.unesco.org/en/list/409 |title=World Heritage List - Hawaii Volcanoes National Park |website=unesco.org |publisher=UNESCO |accessdate=24 February 2017 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170224235652/http://whc.unesco.org/en/list/409 |archivedate=24 February 2017 |deadurl=yes |df= }} (BR) |- !scope="row" | [[Hot Springs National Park|Hot Springs]] |[[File:Hots Springs National Park aerial.jpg|200px]] |[[Arkansas]]
{{coord|34.51|-93.05|name=Hot Springs|type:landmark}} |{{dts|March 4, 1921}} |{{convert|5548.01|acre|km2|1|sortable=on}} |1,561,616 |Hot Springs was established as a federal reserve by Congress on April 20, 1832—the oldest area managed by the National Park Service. Congress redesignated Hot Springs as a national park on March 4, 1921. Natural hot springs flow out of the [[Ouachita Mountains]], providing opportunities for relaxation in a historic setting. [[Bathhouse Row]] preserves numerous examples of 19th-century architecture.{{cite web|url=http://www.nps.gov/hosp/|title=Hot Springs National Park|publisher=National Park Service|accessdate=23 March 2010}} Hot Springs is the first national park in a city and was the smallest national park until February 22, 2018 when the Jefferson National Expansion Memorial was redesignated [[Gateway Arch National Park]].{{cite web |url=https://www.whitehouse.gov/briefings-statements/president-donald-j-trump-signs-s-1438-law/ |title=President Donald J. Trump Signs S. 1438 into Law |work=[[White House]]}} |- |scope="row" bgcolor="#cedff2"| [[Isle Royale National Park|Isle Royale]] {{dagger}} |[[File:IsleRoyalePlane.jpg|200px]] |[[Michigan]]
{{coord|48.10|-88.55|name=Isle Royale|type:landmark}} |{{dts|April 3, 1940}} |{{convert|571790.30|acre|km2|1|sortable=on}} |28,196 |The largest island in [[Lake Superior]] is a place of isolation and wilderness. Along with its many shipwrecks, waterways, and hiking trails, the park also includes over 400 smaller islands within {{convert|4.5|mi|km}} of its shores. There are only 20 mammal species on the entire island, though the relationship between its [[Wolves and moose on Isle Royale|wolf and moose populations]] is especially unique.{{cite web|url=http://www.nps.gov/isro/|title=Isle Royale National Park|publisher=National Park Service|accessdate=23 March 2010}} (BR){{cite web|url=http://www.unesco.org/mabdb/br/brdir/directory/biores.asp?code=USA+33&mode=all |title=Isle Royale Biosphere Reserve and National Park |website=unesco.org |publisher=UNESCO |accessdate=24 February 2017 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170224231145/http://www.unesco.org/mabdb/br/brdir/directory/biores.asp?code=USA%2B33&mode=all |archivedate=24 February 2017 |deadurl=no |df= }} |- |scope="row" bgcolor="#cedff2"| [[Joshua Tree National Park|Joshua Tree]] {{dagger}} |[[File:Joshua Tree - Rock formation in Real Hidden Valley 1.jpg|200px]] |[[California]]
{{coord|33.79|-115.90|name=Joshua Tree|type:landmark}} |{{dts|October 31, 1994}} |{{convert|790635.74|acre|km2|1|sortable=on}} |2,853,619 |Covering large areas of the [[Colorado Desert|Colorado]] and [[Mojave Desert]]s and the [[Little San Bernardino Mountains]], this desert landscape is populated by vast stands of [[Yucca brevifolia|Joshua trees]]. Large changes in elevation reveal various contrasting environments including bleached sand dunes, dry lakes, rugged mountains, and maze-like clusters of [[monzogranite]] monoliths.{{cite web|url=http://www.nps.gov/jotr/|title=Joshua Tree National Park|publisher=National Park Service|accessdate=23 March 2010}} (BR) |- !scope="row" | [[Katmai National Park and Preserve|Katmai]] |[[File:Brown bears brooks falls.jpg|200px]] |[[Alaska]]
{{coord|58.50|-155.00|name=Katmai|type:landmark}} |{{dts|December 2, 1980}} |{{convert|3674529.33|acre|km2|1|sortable=on}} |37,818 |This park on the [[Alaska Peninsula]] protects the [[Valley of Ten Thousand Smokes]], an ash flow formed by the 1912 eruption of [[Novarupta]], as well as [[Mount Katmai]]. Over 2,000 [[grizzly bear]]s come here each year to catch spawning [[salmon]]. Other wildlife includes [[caribou]], [[Northwestern wolf|wolves]], [[moose]], and [[wolverine]]s.{{cite web|url=http://www.nps.gov/katm/|title=Katmai National Park|publisher=National Park Service|accessdate=23 March 2010}} |- !scope="row" | [[Kenai Fjords National Park|Kenai Fjords]] |[[File:Exit Glacier Jul09.JPG|200px]] |[[Alaska]]
{{coord|59.92|-149.65|name=Kenai Fjords|type:landmark}} |{{dts|December 2, 1980}} |{{convert|669650.05|acre|km2|1|sortable=on}} |303,598 |Near [[Seward, Alaska|Seward]] on the [[Kenai Peninsula]], this park protects the [[Harding Icefield]] and at least 38 glaciers and [[fjord]]s stemming from it. The only area accessible to the public by road is [[Exit Glacier]]; the rest must be viewed or reached from boat tours.{{cite web|url=http://www.nps.gov/kefj/|title=Kenai Fjords National Park|publisher=National Park Service|accessdate=23 March 2010}} |- |scope="row" bgcolor="#cedff2"| [[Kings Canyon National Park|Kings Canyon]] {{dagger}} |[[File:KingsCanyonNP.JPG|200px]] |[[California]]
{{coord|36.80|-118.55|name=Kings Canyon|type:landmark}} |{{dts|March 4, 1940}} |{{convert|461901.20|acre|km2|1|sortable=on}} |692,932 |Home to several [[giant sequoia]] groves and the [[General Grant (tree)|General Grant Tree]], the world's second largest measured tree, this park also features part of the [[Kings River (California)|Kings River]], sculptor of the dramatic granite canyon that is its namesake, and the [[San Joaquin River]], as well as Boyden Cave.{{cite web|url=http://www.nps.gov/seki/|title=Kings Canyon National Park|publisher=National Park Service|accessdate=23 March 2010}} Although Kings Canyon National Park was designated as such in 1940, it subsumed General Grant National Park, which had been established on October 1, 1890 as the United States' fourth national park. {{cite web|url=https://www.nps.gov/seki/learn/historyculture/index.htm |title=Kings Canyon National Park|publisher=National Park Service|accessdate=13 July 2018}} {{cite web|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=lDo3AQAAMAAJ&pg=PA35|page=35|title=Sequoia and Kings Canyon National Parks: Final General Management Plan and Comprehensive River Management Plan/Environmental Impact Statement|publisher=U.S. National Park Service|year=2006|accessdate=13 July 2018}}{{cite web|url=https://www.nps.gov/parkhistory/online_books/dilsaver-tweed/chap4c.htm|title=Expansion of Sequoia and Creation of General Grant|publisher=U.S. National Park Service|work=Challenge of the Big Trees|author=Dilsaver, Lary M. |author2=Tweed, William C.|year=1990|accessdate=13 July 2018}}(BR) |- !scope="row" | [[Kobuk Valley National Park|Kobuk Valley]] |[[File:Agie River.jpg|200px]] |[[Alaska]]
{{coord|67.55|-159.28|name=Kobuk Valley|type:landmark}} |{{dts|December 2, 1980}} |{{convert|1750716.16|acre|km2|1|sortable=on}} |15,500 |Kobuk Valley protects {{convert|61|mi|km}} of the [[Kobuk River]] and three regions of sand dunes. Created by glaciers, the Great Kobuk, Little Kobuk, and Hunt River Sand Dunes can reach {{convert|100|ft|m}} high and {{convert|100|F|C}}, and they are the largest dunes in the Arctic. Twice a year, half a million caribou migrate through the dunes and across river bluffs that expose well-preserved ice age fossils.{{cite web|url=http://www.nps.gov/kova/|title=Kobuk Valley National Park|publisher=National Park Service|accessdate=23 March 2010}} |- !scope="row" | [[Lake Clark National Park and Preserve|Lake Clark]] |[[File:Lake Clark National Park.jpg|200px]] |[[Alaska]]
{{coord|60.97|-153.42|name=Lake Clark|type:landmark}} |{{dts|December 2, 1980}} |{{convert|2619816.49|acre|km2|1|sortable=on}} |22,755 |The region around Lake Clark features four active volcanoes, including [[Mount Redoubt]], as well as an abundance of rivers, glaciers, and waterfalls. Temperate rainforests, a tundra plateau, and three mountain ranges complete the landscape.{{cite web|url=http://www.nps.gov/lacl/|title=Lake Clark National Park|publisher=National Park Service|accessdate=23 March 2010}} |- !scope="row" | [[Lassen Volcanic National Park|Lassen Volcanic]] |[[File:Lake Helen - Flickr - Joe Parks.jpg|200px]] |[[California]]
{{coord|40.49|-121.51|name=Lassen Volcanic|type:landmark}} |{{dts|August 9, 1916}} |{{convert|106589.02|acre|km2|1|sortable=on}} |507,256 |[[Lassen Peak]], the largest [[lava dome]] volcano in the world, is joined by all three other types of volcanoes in this park: [[Shield volcano|shield]], [[cinder cone]], and [[Stratovolcano|composite]]. Though Lassen itself last erupted in 1915, most of the rest of the park is continuously active. Numerous hydrothermal features, including [[fumarole]]s, boiling pools, and bubbling mud pots, are heated by molten rock from beneath the peak.{{cite web|url=http://www.nps.gov/lavo/|title=Lassen Volcanic National Park|publisher=National Park Service|accessdate=23 March 2010}} |- |scope="row" bgcolor="#ddcef2"| [[Mammoth Cave National Park|Mammoth Cave]] {{double dagger}} |[[File:Mammoth Cave National Park 007.jpg|200px]] |[[Kentucky]]
{{coord|37.18|-86.10|name=Mammoth Cave|type:landmark}} |{{dts|July 1, 1941}} |{{convert|54011.91|acre|km2|1|sortable=on}} |587,853 |With more than {{convert|400|mi|km}} of passageways explored, Mammoth Cave is the world's longest known cave system. Subterranean wildlife includes eight bat species, [[Kentucky cave shrimp]], [[Northern cavefish]], and cave salamanders. Above ground, the park provides recreation on the [[Green River (Kentucky)|Green River]], 70 miles of hiking trails, and plenty of sinkholes and springs.{{cite web|url=http://www.nps.gov/maca/|title=Mammoth Cave National Park|publisher=National Park Service|accessdate=23 March 2010}} (WHS){{cite web|url=http://whc.unesco.org/en/list/150 |title=World Heritage List - Mammoth Cave National Park |website=unesco.org |publisher=UNESCO |accessdate=24 February 2017 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170224235220/http://whc.unesco.org/en/list/150 |archivedate=24 February 2017 |deadurl=no}} (BR){{cite web|url=http://www.unesco.org/mabdb/br/brdir/directory/biores.asp?code=USA+46&mode=all |title=Biosphere Reserve and National Park |website=unesco.org |publisher=UNESCO |accessdate=24 February 2017 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170224232043/http://www.unesco.org/mabdb/br/brdir/directory/biores.asp?code=USA%2B46&mode=all |archivedate=24 February 2017 |deadurl=no |df= }} |- |scope="row" bgcolor="#cfecd2"| [[Mesa Verde National Park|Mesa Verde]] * |[[File:Mesa Verde National Park Cliff Palace Right Part 2006 09 12.jpg|200px]] |[[Colorado]]
{{coord|37.18|-108.49|name=Mesa Verde|type:landmark}} |{{dts|June 29, 1906}} |{{convert|52485.17|acre|km2|1|sortable=on}} |613,788 |This area constitutes over 4,000 archaeological sites of the [[Ancestral Puebloan]] people, who lived here and elsewhere in the Four Corners region for at least 700 years. Cliff dwellings built in the 12th and 13th centuries include [[Cliff Palace]], which has 150 rooms and 23 [[kiva]]s, and the Balcony House, with its many passages and tunnels.{{cite web|url=http://www.nps.gov/meve/|title=Mesa Verde National Park|publisher=National Park Service|accessdate=23 March 2010}} (WHS){{cite web|url=http://whc.unesco.org/en/list/27 |title=World Heritage List - Mesa Verde National Park |website=unesco.org |publisher=UNESCO |accessdate=24 February 2017 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170224234002/http://whc.unesco.org/en/list/27 |archivedate=24 February 2017 |deadurl=no}} |- !scope="row" | [[Mount Rainier National Park|Mount Rainier]] |[[File:Mount Rainier from west.jpg|200px]] |[[Washington (state)|Washington]]
{{coord|46.85|-121.75|name=Mount Rainier|type:landmark}} |{{dts|March 2, 1899}} |{{convert|236381.64|acre|km2|1|sortable=on}} |1,415,867 |[[Mount Rainier]], an active [[stratovolcano]], is the most [[topographic prominence|prominent]] peak in the [[Cascade Range|Cascades]] and is covered by 26 named glaciers including [[Carbon Glacier]] and [[Emmons Glacier]], the largest in the contiguous United States. The mountain is popular for climbing, and more than half of the park is covered by [[subalpine]] and alpine forests and meadows seasonally in bloom with wildflowers. [[Paradise, Washington|Paradise]] on the south slope is the snowiest place on Earth where snowfall is measured regularly.{{cite web|url=https://www.nps.gov/mora/faqs.htm|title=Mount Rainier National Park-Frequently Asked Questions|publisher=National Park Service|accessdate=28 February 2017}} The [[Longmire, Washington|Longmire]] visitor center is the start of the [[Wonderland Trail]], which encircles the mountain.{{cite web|url=http://www.nps.gov/mora/|title=Mount Rainier National Park|publisher=National Park Service|accessdate=23 March 2010}} |- !scope="row" | [[North Cascades National Park|North Cascades]] |[[File:Cascade pass.jpg|200px]] |[[Washington (state)|Washington]]
{{coord|48.70|-121.20|name=North Cascades|type:landmark}} |{{dts|October 2, 1968}} |{{convert|504780.94|acre|km2|1|sortable=on}} |30,326 |This complex includes two geographically distinct units of the national park, as well as [[Ross Lake National Recreation Area|Ross Lake]] and [[Lake Chelan National Recreation Area]]s. The highly glaciated mountains are spectacular examples of [[Cascade Range|Cascade]] geology. Popular hiking and climbing areas include [[Cascade Pass]], [[Mount Shuksan]], [[Mount Triumph]], and [[Eldorado Peak]].{{cite web|url=http://www.nps.gov/noca/|title=North Cascades National Park|publisher=National Park Service|accessdate=23 March 2010}} |- |scope="row" bgcolor="#ddcef2"| [[Olympic National Park|Olympic]] {{double dagger}} |[[File:Acer macrophyllum in Hoh Rain Forest.jpg|200px]] |[[Washington (state)|Washington]]
{{coord|47.97|-123.50|name=Olympic|type:landmark}} |{{dts|June 29, 1938}} |{{convert|922649.41|acre|km2|1|sortable=on}} |3,401,996 |Situated on the [[Olympic Peninsula]], this park includes a wide range of ecosystems from Pacific shoreline to temperate rainforests to the alpine slopes of the [[Olympic Mountains]], the tallest of which is [[Mount Olympus (Washington)|Mount Olympus]]. The [[Hoh Rainforest]] and [[Quinault Rainforest]] are the wettest area in the contiguous United States, with the Hoh receiving an average of almost {{convert|12|ft|m|abbr=on}} of rain every year.{{cite web|url=https://www.nps.gov/olym/planyourvisit/upload/weather.pdf|title=Olympic National Park-Weather and Climate|publisher=National Park Service|accessdate=28 February 2017}}{{cite web|url=http://www.nps.gov/olym/|title=Olympic National Park|publisher=National Park Service|accessdate=23 March 2010}} (WHS){{cite web|url=http://whc.unesco.org/en/list/151 |title=World Heritage List - Olympic National Park |website=unesco.org |publisher=UNESCO |accessdate=24 February 2017 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170224235319/http://whc.unesco.org/en/list/151 |archivedate=24 February 2017 |deadurl=no}} (BR){{cite web|url=http://www.unesco.org/mabdb/br/brdir/directory/biores.asp?code=USA+17&mode=all |title=Olympic Biosphere Reserve and National Park |website=unesco.org |publisher=UNESCO |accessdate=24 February 2017 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170224225023/http://www.unesco.org/mabdb/br/brdir/directory/biores.asp?code=USA%2B17&mode=all |archivedate=24 February 2017 |deadurl=no |df= }} |- !scope="row" | [[Petrified Forest National Park|Petrified Forest]] |[[File:PAINTED DESERT BADLANDS.jpg|200px]] |[[Arizona]]
{{coord|35.07|-109.78|name=Petrified Forest|type:landmark}} |{{dts|December 9, 1962}} |{{convert|221390.21|acre|km2|1|sortable=on}} |627,757 |This portion of the [[Chinle Formation]] has a large concentration of 225-million-year-old [[petrified wood]]. The surrounding [[Painted Desert, Arizona|Painted Desert]] features eroded cliffs of red-hued volcanic rock called [[bentonite]]. Dinosaur fossils and over 350 Native American sites are also protected in this park.{{cite web|url=http://www.nps.gov/pefo/|title=Petrified Forest National Park|publisher=National Park Service|accessdate=23 March 2010}} |- !scope="row" | [[Pinnacles National Park|Pinnacles]] |[[File:Pinnacles National Park.jpg|200px]] |[[California]]
{{coord|36.48|-121.16|name=Pinnacles|type:landmark}} | {{dts|January 10, 2013}} |{{convert|26685.73|acre|km2|1|sortable=on}} |233,334 |Named for the eroded leftovers of a portion of [[Neenach Volcano|an extinct volcano]], the park's massive black and gold monoliths of [[andesite]] and [[rhyolite]] are a popular destination for [[rock climbing|rock climbers]]. Hikers have access to trails crossing the [[Pacific Coast Range|Coast Range]] wilderness. The park is home to the endangered [[California condor]] (''Gymnogyps californianus'') and one of the few locations in the world where these extremely rare birds can be seen in the wild. Pinnacles also supports a dense population of [[prairie falcon]]s, and more than 13 species of bat which populate its talus caves.{{cite web|url=http://www.nps.gov/pinn/|title=Pinnacles National Monument|date=January 9, 2009|publisher=National Park Service|accessdate=2009-01-24}} |- |scope="row" bgcolor="#cfecd2"| [[Redwood National and State Parks|Redwood]] * |[[File:Redwood National Park, fog in the forest.jpg|200px]] |[[California]]
{{coord|41.30|-124.00|name=Redwood|type:landmark}} |{{dts|October 2, 1968}} |{{convert|138999.37|acre|km2|1|sortable=on}} |445,000 |This park and the co-managed state parks protect almost half of all remaining [[coastal redwood]]s, the tallest trees on earth. There are three large river systems in this very seismically active area, and {{convert|37|mi|km}} of protected coastline reveal tide pools and [[seastack]]s. The prairie, estuary, coast, river, and forest ecosystems contain a wide variety of animal and plant species.{{cite web|url=http://www.nps.gov/redw/|title=Redwood National Park|publisher=National Park Service|accessdate=23 March 2010}} (WHS){{cite web|url=http://whc.unesco.org/en/list/134 |title=World Heritage List - Redwood National and State Parks |website=unesco.org |publisher=UNESCO |accessdate=24 February 2017 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170224235031/http://whc.unesco.org/en/list/134 |archivedate=24 February 2017 |deadurl=no}} |- |scope="row" bgcolor="#cedff2"| [[Rocky Mountain National Park|Rocky Mountain]] {{dagger}} |[[File:Bierstadt Lake, Rocky Mountain National Park, USA.jpg|200px]] |[[Colorado]]
{{coord|40.40|-105.58|name=Rocky Mountain|type:landmark}} |{{dts|January 26, 1915}} |{{convert|265795.20|acre|km2|1|sortable=on}} |4,437,215 |Bisected north to south by the [[Continental Divide of the Americas|Continental Divide]], this portion of the [[Rocky Mountains|Rockies]] has ecosystems varying from over 150 [[riparian]] lakes to montane and subalpine forests to treeless alpine tundra. Wildlife including mule deer, bighorn sheep, black bears, and cougars inhabit its igneous mountains and glacial valleys. [[Longs Peak]], a classic Colorado [[fourteener]], and the scenic [[Bear Lake (Colorado)|Bear Lake]] are popular destinations, as well as the historic [[Trail Ridge Road]], which reaches an elevation of more than {{convert|12000|ft|m}}.{{cite web|url=http://www.nps.gov/romo/|title=Rocky Mountain National Park|publisher=National Park Service|accessdate=23 March 2010}} (BR){{cite web|url=http://www.unesco.org/mabdb/br/brdir/directory/biores.asp?code=USA+19&mode=all |title=Rocky Mountain Biosphere Reserve and National Park |website=unesco.org |publisher=UNESCO |accessdate=24 February 2017 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170224225216/http://www.unesco.org/mabdb/br/brdir/directory/biores.asp?code=USA%2B19&mode=all |archivedate=24 February 2017 |deadurl=no |df= }} |- !scope="row" | [[Saguaro National Park|Saguaro]] |[[File:Saguaronationalparl17102008.jpg|200px]] |[[Arizona]]
{{coord|32.25|-110.50|name=Saguaro|type:landmark}} |{{dts|October 14, 1994}} |{{convert|91715.72|acre|km2|1|sortable=on}} |964,760 |Split into the separate [[Rincon Mountains|Rincon Mountain]] and [[Tucson Mountains|Tucson Mountain]] districts, this park is evidence that the dry [[Sonoran Desert]] is still home to a great variety of life spanning six biotic communities. Beyond the namesake [[saguaro|giant saguaro]] [[cacti]], there are [[barrel cactus|barrel cacti]], [[Cylindropuntia|chollas]], and [[opuntia|prickly pears]], as well as [[lesser long-nosed bat]]s, [[spotted owl]]s, and [[javelina]]s.{{cite web|url=http://www.nps.gov/sagu/|title=Saguaro National Park|publisher=National Park Service|accessdate=23 March 2010}} |- |scope="row" bgcolor="#cedff2"| [[Sequoia National Park|Sequoia]] {{dagger}} |[[File:Giant Forest.jpg|200px]] |[[California]]
{{coord|36.43|-118.68|name=Sequoia|type:landmark}} |{{dts|September 25, 1890}} |{{convert|404062.63|acre|km2|1|sortable=on}} |1,291,256 |This park protects the [[Giant Forest]], which boasts some of the world's largest trees, the [[General Sherman (tree)|General Sherman]] being the largest measured tree in the park. Other features include over 240 caves, a long segment of the [[Sierra Nevada (U.S.)|Sierra Nevada]] including the [[Mount Whitney|tallest mountain in the contiguous United States]], and [[Moro Rock]], a large granite dome.{{cite web|url=http://www.nps.gov/seki/|title=Sequoia National Park|publisher=National Park Service|accessdate=23 March 2010}} (BR){{cite web|url=http://www.unesco.org/mabdb/br/brdir/directory/biores.asp?code=USA+22&mode=all |title=Sequoia and Kings Canyon Biosphere Reserve and National Parks |website=unesco.org |publisher=UNESCO |accessdate=24 February 2017 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170224225522/http://www.unesco.org/mabdb/br/brdir/directory/biores.asp?code=USA%2B22&mode=all |archivedate=24 February 2017 |deadurl=no |df= }} |- !scope="row" | [[Shenandoah National Park|Shenandoah]] |[[File:Early Fall at Dark Hollow Falls (22028259442).jpg|200px]] |[[Virginia]]
{{coord|38.53|-78.35|name=Shenandoah|type:landmark}} |{{dts|December 26, 1935}} |{{convert|199217.77|acre|km2|1|sortable=on}} |1,458,874 |Shenandoah's [[Blue Ridge Mountains]] are covered by hardwood forests that teem with a wide variety of wildlife. The [[Skyline Drive]] and [[Appalachian Trail]] run the entire length of this narrow park, along with more than {{convert|500|mi|km}} of hiking trails passing scenic overlooks and cataracts of the [[Shenandoah River]].{{cite web|url=http://www.nps.gov/shen/|title=Shenandoah National Park|publisher=National Park Service|accessdate=23 March 2010}} |- !scope="row" | [[Theodore Roosevelt National Park|Theodore Roosevelt]] |[[File:Theodore Roosevelt National Park.jpg|200px]] |[[North Dakota]]
{{coord|46.97|-103.45|name=Theodore Roosevelt|type:landmark}} |{{dts|November 10, 1978}} |{{convert|70446.89|acre|km2|1|sortable=on}} |708,003 |This region that enticed and influenced President [[Theodore Roosevelt]] consists of a park of three units in the northern badlands. Besides Roosevelt's [[Theodore Roosevelt's Maltese Cross Cabin|historic cabin]], there are numerous scenic drives and backcountry hiking opportunities. Wildlife includes [[American bison]], [[pronghorn]], [[bighorn sheep]], and wild [[horse]]s.{{cite web|url=http://www.nps.gov/thro/|title=Theodore Roosevelt National Park|publisher=National Park Service|accessdate=23 March 2010}} |- |scope="row" bgcolor="#cedff2"| [[Virgin Islands National Park|Virgin Islands]] {{dagger}} |[[File:St John Trunk Bay 1.jpg|200px]] |[[United States Virgin Islands]]
{{coord|18.33|-64.73|name=Virgin Islands|type:landmark}} |{{dts|August 2, 1956}} |{{convert|14940.00|acre|km2|1|sortable=on}} |304,408 |This island park on [[Saint John, United States Virgin Islands|Saint John]] preserves [[Taíno people|Taíno]] archaeological sites and the ruins of sugar plantations from [[Christopher Columbus|Columbus]]'s time, as well as all the natural environs. Surrounding the pristine beaches are mangrove forests, seagrass beds, and coral reefs.{{cite web|url=http://www.nps.gov/viis/|title=Virgin Islands National Park|publisher=National Park Service|accessdate=23 March 2010}} (BR){{cite web|url=http://www.unesco.org/mabdb/br/brdir/directory/biores.asp?code=USA+25&mode=all |title=Virgin Islands Biosphere Reserve and National Park |website=unesco.org |publisher=UNESCO |accessdate=24 February 2017 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170224230126/http://www.unesco.org/mabdb/br/brdir/directory/biores.asp?code=USA%2B25&mode=all |archivedate=24 February 2017 |deadurl=no |df= }} |- !scope="row" | [[Voyageurs National Park|Voyageurs]] |[[File:Voyageurs National Park.jpg|200px]] |[[Minnesota]]
{{coord|48.50|-92.88|name=Voyageurs|type:landmark}} |{{dts|January 8, 1971}} |{{convert|218200.15|acre|km2|1|sortable=on}} |237,250 |This park protecting four lakes near the Canada–US border is a site for canoeing, kayaking, and fishing. The park also preserves a history populated by [[Ojibwe]] Native Americans, French fur traders called [[Coureur des bois|voyageurs]], and gold miners. Formed by glaciers, the region features tall bluffs, rock gardens, islands, bays, and several historic buildings.{{cite web|url=http://www.nps.gov/voya/|title=Voyageurs National Park|publisher=National Park Service|accessdate=23 March 2010}} |- !scope="row" | [[Wind Cave National Park|Wind Cave]] |[[File:Wind Cave lower.jpg|200px]] |[[South Dakota]]
{{coord|43.57|-103.48|name=Wind Cave|type:landmark}} |{{dts|January 9, 1903}} |{{convert|33970.84|acre|km2|1|sortable=on}} |619,924 |Wind Cave is distinctive for its calcite fin formations called [[boxwork]], a unique formation rarely found elsewhere, and needle-like growths called [[frostwork]]. The cave is one of the longest and most complex caves in the world. Above ground is a mixed-grass prairie with animals such as bison, [[black-footed ferret]]s, and [[prairie dog]]s, and [[ponderosa pine]] forests that are home to [[North American cougar|cougar]]s and [[elk]].{{cite web|url=http://www.nps.gov/wica/|title=Wind Cave National Park|publisher=National Park Service|accessdate=23 March 2010}} The cave is culturally significant to the [[Lakota people]] as the site "from which Wakan Tanka, the Great Mystery, sent the buffalo out into their hunting grounds."{{cite web|url=https://www.nps.gov/wica/learn/historyculture/wind-caves-early-days.htm|title=Wind Cave's Early Days|publisher=National Park Service|accessdate=28 February 2017}} |- |scope="row" bgcolor="#cfecd2"| [[Wrangell–St. Elias National Park and Preserve|Wrangell–St. Elias]] * |[[File:MountJarvis.jpg|200px]] |[[Alaska]]
{{coord|61.00|-142.00|name=Wrangell – St. Elias|type:landmark}} |{{dts|December 2, 1980}} |{{convert|8323146.48|acre|km2|1|sortable=on}} |68,292 |An over {{convert|8|e6acre|km2|0}} plot of mountainous country—the largest national park in the system—protects the convergence of the Alaska, Chugach, and Wrangell-Saint Elias Ranges, which include many of the continent's tallest mountains and volcanoes, including the 18,008-foot [[Mount Saint Elias]]. More than a quarter of the park is covered with glaciers, including the tidewater [[Hubbard Glacier]], piedmont [[Malaspina Glacier]], and valley [[Nabesna Glacier]].{{cite web|url=http://www.nps.gov/wrst/|title=Wrangell – St. Elias National Park|publisher=National Park Service|accessdate=23 March 2010}} (WHS){{cite web|url=http://whc.unesco.org/en/list/72 |title=World Heritage List - Kluane / Wrangell-St. Elias / Glacier Bay / Tatshenshini-Alsek |website=unesco.org |publisher=UNESCO |accessdate=24 February 2017 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170224234804/http://whc.unesco.org/en/list/72 |archivedate=24 February 2017 |deadurl=no}} |- |scope="row" bgcolor="#ddcef2"| [[Yellowstone National Park|Yellowstone]] {{double dagger}} |[[File:Grand Prismatic Spring and Midway Geyser Basin from above.jpg|200px]] |[[Wyoming]], [[Montana]], [[Idaho]]
{{coord|44.60|-110.50|name=Yellowstone|type:landmark}} |{{dts|March 1, 1872}} |{{convert|2219790.71|acre|km2|1|sortable=on}} |4,116,524 |Situated on the [[Yellowstone Caldera]], the park has an expansive network of [[Geothermal areas of Yellowstone|geothermal areas]] including boiling mud pots, vividly colored hot springs such as [[Grand Prismatic Spring]], and regularly erupting geysers, the best-known being [[Old Faithful]]. The yellow-hued [[Grand Canyon of the Yellowstone|Grand Canyon]] of the [[Yellowstone River]] contains several high [[Waterfalls in Yellowstone National Park|waterfalls]], and four mountain ranges traverse the park. More than 60 mammal species including [[Northwestern wolf|gray wolves]], [[grizzly bear]]s, [[American black bear|black bears]], [[Canada lynx|lynxes]], [[American bison|bison]], and [[elk]], make this park one of the best wildlife viewing spots in the country.{{cite web|url=http://www.nps.gov/yell/|title=Yellowstone National Park|publisher=National Park Service|accessdate=23 March 2010}} (WHS){{cite web|url=http://whc.unesco.org/en/list/28 |title=World Heritage List - Yellowstone National Park |website=unesco.org |publisher=UNESCO |accessdate=24 February 2017 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170224234321/http://whc.unesco.org/en/list/28 |archivedate=24 February 2017 |deadurl=no}} (BR){{cite web|url=http://www.unesco.org/mabdb/br/brdir/directory/biores.asp?code=USA+26&mode=all |title=Biosphere Reserve and National Park |website=unesco.org |publisher=UNESCO |accessdate=24 February 2017 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170224230656/http://www.unesco.org/mabdb/br/brdir/directory/biores.asp?code=USA%2B26&mode=all |archivedate=24 February 2017 |deadurl=no |df= }} |- |scope="row" bgcolor="#cfecd2"| [[Yosemite National Park|Yosemite]] * |[[File:YosemitePark2 amk.jpg|200px]] |[[California]]
{{coord|37.83|-119.50|name=Yosemite|type:landmark}} |{{dts|October 1, 1890}} |{{convert|761747.50|acre|km2|1|sortable=on}} |4,336,890 |Yosemite features sheer granite cliffs, exceptionally tall waterfalls, and old-growth forests at a unique intersection of geology and hydrology. [[Half Dome]] and [[El Capitan]] rise from the park's centerpiece, the glacier-carved [[Yosemite Valley]], and from its vertical walls drop [[Yosemite Falls]], one of North America's tallest waterfalls at {{convert|2425|ft|m}} high. Three giant sequoia groves, along with a pristine wilderness in the heart of the [[Sierra Nevada (U.S.)|Sierra Nevada]], are home to a wide variety of rare plant and animal species.{{cite web|url=http://www.nps.gov/yose/|title=Yosemite National Park|publisher=National Park Service|accessdate=23 March 2010}} (WHS){{cite web|url=http://whc.unesco.org/en/list/308 |title=World Heritage List - Yosemite National Park |website=unesco.org |publisher=UNESCO |accessdate=24 February 2017 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170224235557/http://whc.unesco.org/en/list/308 |archivedate=24 February 2017 |deadurl=no}} |- !scope="row" | [[Zion National Park|Zion]] |[[File:Angels Landing.jpg|200px]] |[[Utah]]
{{coord|37.30|-113.05|name=Zion|type:landmark}} |{{dts|November 19, 1919}} |{{convert|147237.02|acre|km2|1|sortable=on}} |4,504,812 |Located at the junction of the [[Colorado Plateau]], [[Great Basin]], and [[Mojave Desert]], this park contains sandstone features such as mesas, rock towers, and canyons, including the [[The Narrows (Zion National Park)|Virgin River Narrows]]. The various sandstone formations and the [[tributary|forks]] of the Virgin River create a wilderness divided into four ecosystems: [[desert]], [[riparian]], [[woodland]], and [[coniferous forest]].{{cite web|url=http://www.nps.gov/zion/|title=Zion National Park|publisher=National Park Service|accessdate=23 March 2010}} |} == See also == * [[List of areas in the United States National Park System]] * [[List of the United States National Park System official units]] * [[History of the National Park Service]] * [[List of National Monuments of the United States]] * [[List of U.S. National Forests]] * [[List of World Heritage Sites in the United States]] == References == {{Reflist|30em}} == External links == {{wikivoyage|United States National Parks}} {{Commons category|National parks of the United States}} {{GeoGroupTemplate}} * {{Official website|http://www.nps.gov/index.htm}} of the [[National Park Service]] * [http://www.nps.gov/findapark/index.htm Find a Park] by the NPS * [https://www.pbs.org/nationalparks/ ''The National Parks: America's Best Idea''] by [[Public Broadcasting Service|PBS]] * [https://irma.nps.gov/Stats/Reports/National Visitor use statistics] * [https://www.washingtonpost.com/graphics/lifestyle/national-parks/?tid=sm_tw America's Natural Heritage - The Essential Guide to the National Parks] by the ''Washington Post'' {{National parks of the United States}} {{US Protected Areas}} {{Featured list}} {{DEFAULTSORT:List Of National Parks Of The United States}} [[Category:Lists of national parks in the United States|*]]

page.title: List of tornadoes in the 2011 Super Outbreak

revision.text:
{{GeoGroupTemplate}} During April 25–28, 2011, the local [[weather forecast office]]s of the [[National Weather Service]] confirmed 359 tornadoes in the [[United States]], and [[Environment Canada]] confirmed another in [[Ontario]]. These tornadoes were part of a major outbreak of tornadoes, the [[2011 Super Outbreak]], in which 360 tornadoes touched down across 21 states in the [[Southern United States|Southern]], [[Midwestern United States|Midwestern]], and [[Northeastern United States]] and in [[Ontario|Ontario, Canada]]. As the outbreak developed on April 25, numerous tornadoes touched down across [[Texas]] and [[Arkansas]], with an EF3 near [[Hot Springs Village, Arkansas]] that caused significant damage and killed one person and a long-track EF2 tornado in the [[Vilonia, Arkansas]] area that killed four people and injured 16 others after being on the ground for over one hour.{{cite web|title=20110425's Storm Reports (1200 UTC − 1159 UTC)|url=http://www.spc.noaa.gov/climo/reports/110425_rpts.html|work=[[Storm Prediction Center]]|publisher=[[National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration]]|accessdate=January 12, 2014|date=April 25, 2011}}{{cite web|work=National Weather Service Office in Little Rock, Arkansas|publisher=National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration|date=May 14, 2011|accessdate=December 30, 2013|title=Heavy Rain/Severe Weather on April 23–27, 2011|url=http://www.srh.noaa.gov/lzk/?n=rain0411yr.htm}} April 26 saw no deaths and mostly weaker tornadoes, with the notable tornadoes of the day being an EF2 tornado that tracked across parts of Texas and into [[Louisiana]] and a brief EF3 that struck [[Campbell Army Airfield]], causing $1 million (2011 [[United States dollar|USD]]) in damage. From the 27th to 28th, a series of devastating, long-tracked, violent tornadoes killed hundreds of people throughout an area extending from [[Mississippi]] to [[Virginia]]. This included eleven EF4s and four EF5s. One particularly devastating and long-lived EF5 wedge tornado tore across northern [[Alabama]] and into [[Tennessee]], killing 72 people and devastating several small towns, particularly [[Hackleburg, Alabama|Hackleburg]], [[Phil Campbell, Alabama|Phil Campbell]], [[Tanner, Alabama|Tanner]], and [[Harvest, Alabama|Harvest]]. A large, long-tracked EF4 was broadcast live on multiple TV stations as it caused catastrophic damage in densely populated areas of [[Tuscaloosa, Alabama|Tuscaloosa]] and [[Birmingham, Alabama]], killing 64 people. Numerous other small towns including [[Smithville, Mississippi]]; [[Cordova, Alabama]]; [[Rainsville, Alabama]]; [[Ohatchee, Alabama]]; [[Cullman, Alabama]]; [[Trenton, Georgia]]; [[Ringgold, Georgia]]; [[Apison, Tennessee]]; and [[Glade Spring, Virginia]] sustained devastating, direct hits from intense tornadoes, with several producing death tolls well into the double digits. 319 additional tornado-related deaths occurred within those two days before the outbreak came to an end, bringing the total death toll to 324.{{cite web|title=20110426's Storm Reports (1200 UTC − 1159 UTC)|url=http://www.spc.noaa.gov/climo/reports/110426_rpts.html|work=[[Storm Prediction Center]]|publisher=[[National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration]]|accessdate=January 12, 2014|date=April 26, 2011}}{{cite web|work=[[National Weather Service]] Office in Shreveport, Louisiana|publisher=National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration|date=April 27, 2011|accessdate=January 4, 2014|title=Severe Weather Hits the Four State Region April 24–27, 2011|url=http://www.srh.noaa.gov/shv/?n=stormsurveys_april25-27_2011}}{{cite web|work=National Weather Service Office in Paducah, Kentucky|publisher=National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration|date=May 5, 2011|accessdate=January 4, 2014|title=Damage Survey Results For Ft. Campbell, KY|url=http://mesonet.agron.iastate.edu/wx/afos/p.php?pil=PNSPAH&e=201105052113}} ==Confirmed tornadoes== {|class="wikitable" style="text-align:center;font-size: 9pt" |- !rowspan="3"|State/
